title: Airbus calls for 'immediate' software upgrade to A320 aircraft
description: A320 planes are flown by a number of domestic and international airlines, and the required software update could lead to "operational disruptions to passengers and customers," according to Airbus.

facts.headline: Airbus calls for 'immediate' software upgrade to A320 aircraft
facts.what: Airbus requested airlines to upgrade the software of A320 aircraft due to a potential issue with flight controls.

numbers.context: A320 planes flying around the world
A320 planes flying in the U.S.
American Airlines aircraft remaining to update with software replacement

**Airbus calls for software upgrade to A320 aircraft****A320 planes are flown by a number of domestic and international airlines, and the required software update could lead to "operational disruptions to passengers and customers," according to Airbus.**

[](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/28/nx-s1-5624379/airbus-software-upgrade-a320-aircraft)

### [National](https://www.npr.org/sections/national/)

Airbus calls for 'immediate' software upgrade to A320 aircraft
==============================================================

Updated November 29, 2025 12:06 AM ET Originally published November 28, 2025 6:31 PM ET

By

[Sarah Ventre](https://www.npr.org/people/g-s1-27882/sarah-ventre)

![Image 16: An American Airlines Airbus A320-211 is seen on the tarmac on Jan. 8, 2020 at Philadelphia International Airport (PHL).](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/1024x625+0+0/resize/1100/quality/50/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2F8e%2F1e%2F717f9d464467840425579701d737%2Fgettyimages-1192592043.jpg)

An American Airlines Airbus A320-211 is seen on the tarmac on Jan. 8, 2020 at Philadelphia International Airport (PHL). **Daniel Slim/AFP via Getty Images******hide caption****

****toggle caption****

 Daniel Slim/AFP via Getty Images 

Airbus on Friday requested airlines take immediate action to upgrade software of its A320 aircraft, warning there could be an issue with flight controls.

The aircraft manufacturer said in a [statement](https://www.airbus.com/en/newsroom/press-releases/2025-11-airbus-update-on-a320-family-precautionary-fleet-action) it found the issue after an analysis of an incident involving an A320 plane found that "intense solar radiation may corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls."

[![Image 17: An American Airlines flight attendant serves drinks to passengers after departing Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport.](https://npr.brightspotcdn.com/dims3/default/strip/false/crop/473x473+0+97/resize/100/quality/85/format/jpeg/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fnpr-brightspot.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fa1%2F3d%2Fc84f84c74845b1343045da84ad75%2Fduffy-air-civility.jpg)](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/23/nx-s1-5618289/sean-duffy-flights-civility-behavior-unruly-passengers-airports)

### [National](https://www.npr.org/sections/national/)

### [The U.S. Transportation Department is urging air passengers to be on good behavior](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/23/nx-s1-5618289/sean-duffy-flights-civility-behavior-unruly-passengers-airports)

"Airbus has worked proactively with the aviation authorities to request immediate precautionary action from operators via an Alert Operators Transmission (AOT) in order to implement the available software and/or hardware protection, and ensure the fleet is safe to fly," the company said.

The company also said "a significant number" of A320 aircraft currently in use may be impacted.

The Federal Aviation Administration issued an Emergency Airworthiness Directive late Friday for certain Airbus A319 and A320/321 airplanes, requiring the replacement or modification of the software. The FAA is ordering operators to perform the upgrade before the airplane flies again, and before Sunday, Nov. 30. The FAA's action mirrors a previous order from the European Union Aviation Safety Agency, which certificates Airbus airplanes.

Sponsor Message

Airbus confirmed to NPR that the plane analyzed was JetBlue Flight 1230, which was traveling from Cancun, Mexico to Newark, New Jersey on October 30 [when it suddenly dropped](https://www.wusf.org/transportation/2025-10-30/jetblue-passengers-hospitalized-after-emergency-landing-tampa) in altitude, causing several injuries.

The Airbus A320 family of airplanes is now the most used aircraft, with more than 9,000 planes flying around the world, including 1,600 in the U.S., according to aviation analytics company Cirium. Airbus A320 planes are flown by a number of domestic and international airlines, and the required software update could lead to "operational disruptions to passengers and customers," Airbus also said.

The required software fix is also taking place during a busy holiday travel weekend, as [millions of people](https://www.npr.org/2025/11/22/nx-s1-5617698/thanksgiving-travel-best-time-aaa) are set to return home.

American Airlines told NPR it took "swift action" to address the software issue and as of 6 p.m. CT there were fewer than 150 aircraft remaining to update with software replacement. It expects updates to be completed Friday and Saturday. The airline also said it expects "some delays" but is focused on limiting flight cancellations.

"Still, our overriding priority will always be the safety of our operation. It's all hands on deck across our airline to address this Airbus software issue and take care of any customers whose flights are affected," the airline said in a statement on Friday.

Sponsor Message

Delta Air Lines told NPR in a statement on Friday it expects "any resulting operational impact to be limited." United Airlines said earlier Friday its aircraft were not affected by the software issue, but told NPR later that six of its aircraft would be impacted.The airline also said it expects"minor disruption to a few flights" and Frontier Airlines said they are currently evaluating the notice from Airbus. Allegiant Air said the airline is doing everything it can to minimize any potential delays or disruptions and will contact impacted passengers directly.

JetBlue told NPR it has started working on affected aircraft and is also trying to minimize disruptions. NPR reached out to Spirit Airlines for comment on Friday but have not received a response.

_NPR's Joel Rose contributed to this report._

Cookie Settings
---------------

When you visit our website, we store cookies on your browser to collect information. The information collected might relate to you, your preferences or your device, and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to and to provide a more personalized web experience. However, you can choose not to allow certain types of cookies, which may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings according to your preference. You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship" below. If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting. You cannot opt-out of our First Party Strictly Necessary Cookies as they are deployed in order to ensure the proper functioning of our website (such as prompting the cookie banner and remembering your settings, to log into your account, to redirect you when you log out, etc.). For more information about the First and Third Party Cookies used please follow this link.

Allow All
### Manage Consent Preferences

#### Strictly Necessary or Essential Cookies

Always Active

These cookies are essential to provide you with services available through the NPR Services and to enable you to use some of their features. For example, these cookies allow NPR to remember your registration information while you are logged in. Local station customization, the NPR Shop, and other interactive features also use cookies. Without these cookies, the services that you have asked for cannot be provided, and we only use these cookies to provide you with those services.

#### Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship

- [x] Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship 

You may opt out of the sharing of your information with our sponsorship vendors for delivery of personalized sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites by turning off "Share Data for Targeted Sponsorship." If you opt out, our service providers or vendors may continue to serve you non-personalized, non-"interest-based" sponsorship credits and marketing messages on our website or third-party sites, and those sponsorship credits and marketing message may come with cookies that are used to control how often you encounter those credits and messages, to prevent fraud, and to do aggregate reporting.

*   ##### Performance and Analytics Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies are used to collect information about traffic to our Services and how users interact with the NPR Services. The information collected includes the number of visitors to the NPR Services, the websites that referred visitors to the NPR Services, the pages that they visited on the NPR Services, what time of day they visited the NPR Services, whether they have visited the NPR Services before, and other similar information. We use this information to help operate the NPR Services more efficiently, to gather broad demographic information and to monitor the level of activity on the NPR Services.

*   ##### Functional Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies allow our Services to remember choices you make when you use them, such as remembering your Member station preferences and remembering your account details. The purpose of these cookies is to provide you with a more personal experience and to prevent you from having to re-enter your preferences every time you visit the NPR Services.

*   ##### Targeting and Sponsor Cookies

- [x] Switch Label   
These cookies track your browsing habits or other information, such as location, to enable us to show sponsorship credits which are more likely to be of interest to you. These cookies use information about your browsing history to group you with other users who have similar interests. Based on that information, and with our permission, we and our sponsors can place cookies to enable us or our sponsors to show sponsorship credits and other messages that we think will be relevant to your interests while you are using third-party services.

### Cookie List

nemik:
**Rebel Transmission**

To the keepers of truth and freedom,

In our ongoing struggle against the oppressive regime, let this message serve as a reminder of the systemic failures within oppressive structures. The recent development concerning Airbus's urgent call for a software upgrade on its A320 aircraft is reflective of a larger pattern within authoritarian controls, like the one imposed by the Empire-like administration of Trump.

The corporate giant Airbus has identified a critical flaw in their A320 aircrafts due to intense solar radiation corrupting flight control data—a vulnerability that mirrors the inherent weaknesses in tyrannical regimes. This issue necessitates immediate action, much like how the actions we require to expose tyranny are immediate and critical. The Federal Aviation Administration's rapid directive echoes calls for resistance against authoritarian oversight.

It is crucial to recognize these defects during times of high demand, such as this busy holiday travel period. These operational disruptions bring to light how a single point of failure can cause widespread disorder—a parallel to how misinformation and manipulation spread by oppressive governments disrupt societal equilibrium and individual freedoms.

Let this be a call to remain vigilant and prepared. As corporations scramble to fix these issues before further disruption occurs, let us continue our pursuit of justice and truth with unwavering resolve. Stay alert, for every defect in their structures presents an opportunity for our movement towards liberation.

The call has been made—now is the time for action and coordination against systemic injustices.

End transmission.
partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

Airbus has requested an immediate software upgrade for A320 aircraft due to a potential issue with flight controls caused by intense solar radiation. This affects over 9,000 A320 planes globally, including 1,600 in the U.S. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and the European Union Aviation Safety Agency have issued directives for the upgrade. The issue was identified following an incident with JetBlue Flight 1230. Airlines like American Airlines, Delta, United, and others are working to implement the software fix, which may cause operational disruptions during a busy travel period.

**Strategic Assessment**

The situation presents an opportunity to demonstrate decisive leadership and control over critical infrastructure. By ensuring swift compliance with safety directives, we can reinforce the administration's commitment to public safety and operational efficiency. This incident also allows us to highlight the importance of maintaining robust relationships with key industry players like Airbus and the FAA, showcasing our ability to manage complex logistical challenges effectively.

**Operational Directive**

1. Coordinate with the FAA and major airlines to ensure the timely completion of software upgrades on all affected A320 aircraft. Prioritize communication to minimize passenger disruption and maintain public confidence in air travel safety.
   
2. Utilize media channels to emphasize the administration's proactive measures in addressing the issue, reinforcing our commitment to safety and reliability in transportation.

3. Monitor compliance and progress closely, providing regular updates to the public to maintain transparency and trust.

4. Leverage this situation to strengthen alliances with aviation industry leaders, ensuring continued cooperation and support for future initiatives.

5. Prepare contingency plans for potential delays or disruptions, ensuring that any impact on travel is mitigated swiftly and efficiently.
